review.title: Employing traditional machine learning algorithms for big data streams analysis: the case of object trajectory prediction
review.abstract: In this paper, we model the trajectory of sea vessels and provide a service that predicts in near-real time the position of any given vessel in 4', 10', 20' and 40' time intervals. We explore the necessary tradeoffs between accuracy, performance and resource utilization are explored given the large volume and update rates of input data. We start with building models based on well-established machine learning algorithms using static datasets and multi-scan training approaches and identify the best candidate to be used in implementing a single-pass predictive approach, under real-time constraints. The results are measured in terms of accuracy and performance and are compared against the baseline kinematic equations. Results show that it is possible to efficiently model the trajectory of multiple vessels using a single model, which is trained and evaluated using an adequately large, static dataset, thus achieving a significant gain in terms of resource usage while not compromising accuracy.

metadata.title: Employing traditional machine learning algorithms for big data streams analysis: the case of object trajectory prediction

sections.text: In this paper, we model the trajectory of seagoing vessels and offer a service that predicts the position of any ship in near-real-time intervals of 4 ', 10', 20 'and 40'. We investigate the necessary trade-offs between accuracy, performance and resource usage given the large volume and update rates of input data. We start by building models based on well-established machine learning algorithms using static data sets and multi-scan training approaches, and identify the best candidate that can be used in implementing a single-pass prediction approach under real-time constraints. Results are measured in terms of accuracy and performance and compared with kinematic equations. Results show that it is possible to efficiently model the trajectory of multiple ships using a single model that is trained and evaluated using a sufficiently large static dataset, achieving a significant gain in terms of resource usage without compromising accuracy.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: From the point of view of the data stream, we have looked for relevant solutions in the field of time series and real-time analysis, while at the same time examining the traditional algorithms used for the problem of orbit prediction. Below, we present our research on these two classes. To our knowledge, there is not a single work in the current literature that compares big data predictive analytics for orbit prediction in real-time.

sections.heading: 2.1 Time-series, Real-time Analysis Tools
sections.text: There are two logical methods of process data streams: maintaining a small number of elements that characterize the data stream (and often the application we are tackling), and requiring much smaller space and time to process it. Fixed parts of the data are loaded into a memory buffer, and the machine algorithms are applied only when they also take into account past performance for optimization.

sections.heading: 2.2 Trajectory Prediction Models
sections.text: In terms of models for predicting moving models and maneuvers used in recent literature, they can be divided into three categories that take into account their dimensional space: 1-D, 2-D and 3-D. The 3-D models are commonly used in air traffic control systems, and 1-D and 2-D models are commonly used in land and maritime systems [19]. If a single model cannot capture the required behavior of a target, a multiple model approach has also been proposed. In [20] Ristic et al, we use historical AIS ship motion patterns to predict the movement of a ship based on the Gaussian sum filter.

sections.heading: 3 Approach
sections.text: As mentioned above, the central challenge facing this work revolved around the real-time prediction of the trajectories of seagoing ships using real data streams that communicate their position, direction, ID and some other metadata. This research is motivated by the fact that providing valid and accurate estimates of future ship positions includes valuable knowledge for decision-making processes by shipowners, insurance companies, coastguards, port management, etc. The prediction model is based on the premise that a ship's past behavior can help to derive knowledge about its future position. As we refer to data streams, it is crucial to clarify that the definition of past behavior is subtle and largely depends on time and computational resource constraints. As shown in [26], when large amounts of historical motion recordings are available and multiple scans of the data can be tolerated, the results can be remarkably accurate.

sections.heading: 3.1 Baseline work
sections.text: In our previous paper [6], we used a fixed time window processing model and applied a series of semi-supervised learning methods. The key concept is that for each batch fed into the algorithm, the prediction was measured against the actual position, which was then reported in the immediate future, using an iterative process to refine the model. Thus, the performance of the prediction algorithm was such that the result was at least one unit of time ahead of the record with the predicted position. Each algorithm made a prediction with the fixed window stack and evaluated itself by performing a training step against the actual position. All algorithms suffered from the cold start problem, especially because there was no distinction between the semantics of the vessels, i.e. each vessel record was treated as a record that contributed equally to the model. This simply means that there was no separation of models between vessels, geographic areas or other distinct parameters of the model, even if there were clear intuitions reported in our previous paper [26].

sections.heading: 3.2 Assumptions and approach
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this project is a project, which is a project that is, first and foremost, a project that aims to put people's needs at the centre and, first and foremost, to put people's needs at the centre.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Data and pre-Processing
sections.text: The data set included 1,315,474 AIS entries relating to 2,874 unique vessels, including all types of vessels (cargo, tankers and passenger vessels, fishing boats and recreational craft) operating in the Aegean Sea (especially in the range of latitude from 36,08462 to 39,48708 and length from 24,45557 to 26,58691), for a period of 30 days starting on 1 November 2014. To satisfy this need, we use the entire data set and apply 10-fold cross validation, using the same split in all models. When implementing the real-time data stream analysis service, we need to maintain a number of entries in order to evaluate our system.

sections.heading: 4.2 Machine Learning Models
sections.text: We constructed two models for each set of different "prediction interval" fields, one for predicting latitude, and one for longitude, and tested various applicable configurations that flirt with the models "input features (latitude, longitude, speed, course). However, some combinations of the set of these options were not feasible, while some other parameters such as the instances taken into account for training and evaluating the model. A particular example refers to the amount of subsequent data sets in a 20" time interval. The results show the superiority of a 10-node training, multi-layer perception.

sections.heading: 4.3 Evaluation of the real-time data-stream analysis service
sections.text: This year, the number of new arrivals to the US is many times higher than in previous years.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: This work focuses on modelling the trajectory of ships through real-time analysis, monitoring, spatio-temporal time series. The model does not make assumptions and categorisations between ship characteristics, nor does it take into account application semantics, but rather attempts to process the data stream as it arrives, provided that each new dataset equally contributes to a single trajectory forecasting model. This limitation is set to ensure the replicability and scalability of the model, to any moving object-object forecasting model. Unlike previous approaches, which considered specific implementations of machine learning algorithms, in this work we use a forward model based on traditional multi-scan machine learning algorithms. We show that the model can help with real-time queries that achieve better accuracy than simple kinematic learning model 31.

In real-time analysis, queries should run continuously; logically issued once, but run forever [3].
To discover knowledge or patterns from data streams, it is necessary to develop single-scan, on-line, multilevel, multidimensional stream processing and analysis methods [4].

Learning algorithms have to exhibit characteristics of incremental and adaptive learning incorporating concept of drift, forgetting outdated data and adapting to the most recent state of the nature to be relevant [5].

A generally acceptable assumption is that traditional methods of frequent item set mining, classification, and clustering tend to scan the data multiple times, making them inadequate for stream data [4].

This assumption was the premise for our previous work [6] in which we built a system capable of predicting multiple vessels behavior from streaming data under real-time constraints, employing single scan, fixed window algorithms and a toolkit called Massive Online Analysis (MOA) [7].

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we model the trajectory of sea vessels and provide a service that predicts in near-real time the position of any given vessel in 4’, 10’, 20’ and 40’ time intervals. We explore the necessary tradeoffs between accuracy, performance and resource utilization are explored given the large volume and update rates of input data. We start with building models based on well-established machine learning algorithms using static datasets and multi-scan training approaches and identify the best candidate to be used in implementing a single-pass predictive approach, under real-time constraints. The results are measured in terms of accuracy and performance and are compared against the baseline kinematic equations. Results show that it is possible to efficiently model the trajectory of multiple vessels using a single model, which is trained and evaluated using an adequately large, static dataset, thus achieving a significant gain in terms of resource usage while not compromising accuracy.
